awd_titl_txt: Fusing Equity and Whole-School STEM Models: A Conference Proposal
awd_abstract_narration:
Interest in whole-school STEM education models is rapidly expanding in the United States, but there is limited agreement on the essential features of effective STEM schools and a limited research base on effective practices. There are also concerns regarding equity issues associated with whole-school STEM models. This project will address these issues by planning, implementing, and evaluating the outcomes of an invitational conference on the role of equity in whole-school STEM education models, particularly Inclusive STEM Schools (ISS), at the high school level. The conference will include 25 invited participants who have expertise as researchers or practitioners in equity issues or whole-school STEM reform efforts. These participants will discuss how to: 1) Create a collective understanding among a community of stakeholders regarding the role of equity in whole-school STEM models, 2) Map, synthesize, and report the terrain of existing research around the role of equity in whole-school STEM and non-STEM models including both strengths and gaps in the research base, and 3) Identify central issues and questions that can guide future research in order to prioritize these topics and initiate productive collaborations among participants to pursue answers to critical questions. These discussions will result in two key outcomes: 1) A practitioner centered logic model that integrates equity into the design and implementation of STEM at the whole-school level, and 2) A research model that supports building an empirical understanding of the intersection between equity and whole-school STEM programs.

There are various models of STEM-centered schools, with the most significant difference across models being the enrollment criteria. This project will focus on Inclusive STEM Schools which have open enrollment and provide paths for all students to advanced learning or careers in STEM fields. Federal initiatives have promoted and supported expansion of these schools, but there is little research on the impacts of these schools, and even less research on the role of equity considerations on the design and implementation of these schools. This project will address the limited research base by focusing specifically on culturally relevant and culturally responsive programing for inclusive STEM schools and initiating a research agenda on the role of equity in designing inclusive STEM programs. The project will seek to identify effective practices, and document outcomes on diverse populations.

The Discovery Research preK-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The impetus for this conference came from the Museum of Science & Industry, Chicago?s Science Leadership Initiative (SLI) research findings, which demonstrated a lack of literature and knowledge around equity in whole-school STEM reform contexts. Developed in 2015 as a response to the need for deeper training amongst whole-school STEM leaders in Chicago, the SLI program provides leaders and teams with rigorous skill development and tools to employ STEM across classrooms and activities. In 2018, after the first cohort of SLI leaders completed training, research findings showed that school staff reported problems with equity and culture at their school.

 

In light of these findings, MSI performed a literature review to search for best practices around equity issues in whole-school STEM reform. Researchers found limited theoretical advice and empirically-based research on the intersection between the roles of equity in whole-school STEM reform. It became clear that there is a significant gap in the STEM reform literature on this topic. However, there is a considerable amount of literature on equity in the non-STEM, whole-school reform field. So what is the best way to take what is known in the non-STEM field and apply it to the whole-school reform STEM field? Due to the complexities, sensitivities and nuances of the topic, and the time needed to do justice to such a discussion, MSI felt that a multi-day, in-person conference bringing together representatives from these areas would benefit the field as opposed to a piecemeal approach spread across fields, dates and formats.

 

Unfortunately, the COVID pandemic led to a two-year postponement of the conference. In spring 2022, the reconstituted conference shifted to a virtual format where researchers, policy-makers, and practitioners shared their visions of equity in STEM over the course of three days. The presentations and synthesis shared here set the stage for future empirical studies of equity in STEM education and whole-school reform. Findings from these presentations are primarily informal, as per our goal of providing concrete, practical findings for a broad audience of leaders, teachers, school staff and community partners, parents, and researchers. The goals of this conference were to bring together a small group to discuss how to:

 

(1) Create a collective understanding among a community of stakeholders regarding the role of equity in whole-school STEM models,

(2) Map, synthesize and report the terrain of existing research around the role of equity in whole-school STEM and non-STEM models, including both strengths and gaps in the research base, and

(3) Identify central issues and questions that can guide future research to prioritize these topics and initiate productive collaborations among participants to pursue questions.

 

Equity in STEM education is not ?if you build it, they will come.? Simply placing a student in a STEM program or school is not enough to assume that their outcomes will be the same as other students. This conference has taught us that a multi-strand approach is necessary for all students to have equitable opportunities. While not all equity frameworks use the same language (an area for future research), many use similar concepts and strategies. These frameworks represent a ?to-do? list for creating equity at the district, school, and classroom levels. While strategies range from broad school norms to a student?s individual math problems, successful equity means that each student experiences instruction to meet their own individual needs and interests. This happens through large-scale policies such as resource equity reform, as well as small-scale experiences such as the adaptation of a math problem. A challenge for researchers studying STEM equity is that, according to the frameworks presented at this conference, each student necessarily has a very different set of unique learning experiences based on their identity, skills, and interests. This complexity may be difficult initially for researchers to study as part of summative assessments. More qualitative studies on how STEM equity practices are implemented may help researchers and stakeholders begin to codify the critical conceptual (and practical) elements of equity in STEM education. By improving the quality of equitable STEM learning (as well as research studies to understand these diverse effects), we can disseminate accessible, practical strategies to improve the experiences of all learners.
